answers.author: Pat Parkhurst
answers.text:
The City of Bothell is currently purchasing our fuel from the Northshore School District.  The District purchases the fuel at bulk rates and passes the savings on to us with a small administrative fee.  This has saved us considerable $$ (one specific day in April, our diesel purchses at the school district were $.70 less per gallon than at the local gas station.  We also have obtained "fueling cards" from Comdata which allow us to purchase fuel at any gas station.  We receive a small discount on fuel purchased this way.  We need to options not only for emergency pruposes but because it is not necessarily cost effective for all our vehicles to be driven to the School District site.

answers.author: Andrew Mair
answers.text:
I have had responsibilities for fleet management, in various venues, since 1982 and have had on and off experience w/ alternate fuels since 1990.  I only have rented tanks or used "fuel cards" or comparable contracted purchasing for interim periods when construction was underway.  It always has been cost effective in my circumstances to own the tanks, pay for them through capital projects funds,  and either bid the fuel or, if you have suffucient resources in Purchasing, to buy on the spot market.  In my current position I am midway between the NYC and Philadelphia markets and have been successful in negotiating the index prices at Philadelphia rates.  PC based fuel disensing systems are relatively inexpensive, robust and not only allow for control and chargeback of costs through whatever cost allocation plans are pertinent to you but also include leak detection, audit of deliveries to ensure against overcharging and tracking (and enforcement) of vehicle maintenance schedules.  Bottom line is that I feel I have more control over my fleet and fuel by keeping its operation in-house.   Changing tanks is anopportunity to consider conversion to alternate fules withour incurring recundant infrastructure cosats, an opportunity you may wish to consider if it is not on the table already.

answers.author: Anne Marie Green
answers.text:
The County of Roanoke Virginia uses a hybrid system.  We have fuel cards through Wright Express for most vehicles.  This allows us to fuel wherever is most convenient and cheapest, saving many miles in a county tha tis 240 square miles.  Wright Express data is imported into FASTER, so that we can keep track of fuel and bill to the departments.
Fire and Rescue, located in sometimes rural areas, has above ground gas and diesel tanks - fuel is purchased on the spot market.
We also have underground gas and diesel tanks at our public service center, allowing for fueling for heavy equipment and garbage trucks.  We purchase on the spot market for that also.
New EPA regulations are coming down about training and accountability for underground tanks - we will probably have to replace ours, and don't have any funding to do so.  While I believe it is good to always have your own supply, partnering with the private sector has saved us a lot of time and money.

answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
The City of Albany, Oregon relys on outside fueling. The majority of fuel is obtained through Linn County who maintains a fueling facility. Our Police Department gets 100% of their by using a commercial cardlock provider. Fire, Public Works and Parks & Recreation selectively use cardlock fueling for convienence to avoid having to haul equipment across town to the county facility.
This approach means that we have no facilities/equipment costs that need to be paid - vendors pick that up.
The county is our cheapest provider.  While comparisons are tough because wholesale and commercial fuel prices can change every day, the county appears to change once or twice per month (probably after they get deliveries). 
Our commercial prices for Police/PW/Parks is around .04 per gallon more than the county. Fire has found that their non-contracted cardlock costs shot up to as much as 0.50 per gallon higher thaan with the county for diesel.
We are about to go out to bid for city-wide cardlock services to standardize the prices and delivery. Currently, a State of Oregon cooperative contract foer commercial cardlock services is available @ 0.16 over wholesale. However our Police expeirence lead us to believe we can beat that price significantly

answers.author: Sam Anselm
answers.text:
Joplin, MO owns its own tanks, and we can usually beat the local fuel suppliers in price.  In addition, we use a fuel tracking system that tracks mileage when employees use the pump, which then feeds into our preventive maintenance system and automatically schedules service based on the number of miles on the vehicle or piece of equipment.

answers.author: Austin Abraham
answers.text:
Frederick County, MD uses 1,000,000 gallons of fuel (diesel and gasoline) per year and has 6 fueling depots, soon to be 7.  We currently have fuel provided to our tanks by Fleetcor (Fuelman) on consignment, billed to us as dispensed, and transaction data with provided by Fleetcor that we upload into CCG Faster.  We are converting in the next few months to owning our own fuel which will save us $60,000 per year in fees, with little additional administrative burden.  Regulations related to UST's and AST's can be time consuming: EPA inventory monitoring and control regs, State, stormwater pollution prevention plans, spill prevention plans, etc.) but those fall to the owner regardless of who owns the fuel in the tanks.  Stockpiling fuel around our County (660 sq miles) is an integral part of emergency preparedness for us.  We have experienced snow storms when retail fueling sites simply were not open for business.  Our fuel cards are also good for purchases at Fuelman-approved retail locations when users are not convenient to  County fuel depot.  We are currently in discussions with Frederick City, the public schools and the local community college about sharing the use of fueling sites among our agencies.  Feel free to contact me if you would like to discuss in more detail.

answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
The City of Fort Lauderdale has a fleet of approx. 1500 vehicles, including everything from autos to excavators and 15 fire engines.  We have had underground storage tanks for several years, and two years ago, purchased two fueling trucks, so that can both store fuel in the trucks, but also use the trucks to fuel vehicles anywhere in the City.  The City is part of a larger cooperative group that competes fuel supply.  Our pricing is based on what is called the OPIS index (Oil Petroleum Index Service).  Essentially, we pay cost plus a markup tied to the index. We are currently exploring hedging our fuel purchases for purposes of being able to budget fuel expenditures on a more consistent basis.

author: Douglas Brimm
text:
The City of Collinsville is currently exploring alternative options for fueling its fleet.  The fleet includes 29 sedans (primarily police cruisers), 1 utility/service van, 42 trucks and SUVs, 2 shuttle buses, 4 ambulance or rescue transport vehicles, 3 fire engines, and 1 aerial ladder engine.  These vehicles utilize unleaded and diesel fuel.   Additionally, the City has 45 pieces of large equipment such as excavators, backhoes, utility dump trucks, street sweepers, and generators; and has 96 “small equipment units”, including mowers, chain saws, weed eaters, spray machines, and snow blowers.
Currently, the City owns its own unleaded and diesel pumps, but an outside firm owns the above ground storage tanks and also supplies both fuels.  We are experiencing issues related to the maintenance of the above ground storage tanks which is causing issues in our police cruisers’ fuel systems.
We would like to use this as an opportunity to explore alternative options relating to fuel supply, including:
• Utilizing fleet cards (however this may pose an issue when fueling large equipment – excavators, backhoes, fire engines);
• Purchasing our own storage tanks and bidding out fuel supply; and
• Bidding/Contracting for new pumps/storage tanks and fuel supply.
We are interested in how other local governments manage fuel for their fleets (any of the above options, terms of agreements, anything not listed above, etc.).
Thank you for your time!
title: Municipal Fuel Options
